page.title: 14ST.JAMES THE GREAT
page.content: Except for a few minor alterations the {Nave}of the Church remains as it was in the twelfth century. A pleasing feature of the Church are the{wall {paintings,}unique in England for their detail and variety, where the whole central zone of the Nave is devoted to the life of{St. James the Great. In the twelfth century, the shrine of St. James at Compostella in Northern Spain was an important centre of pilgrimage. St. James was venerated as the oldest of the apostles and, since he was the first to suffer martydom, as the first apostle to enter heaven. The dedication of the Church reflects the widespread cult of the saint. It is likely that the paintings were the gift of a wealthy patron or Lord of the Manor, possibly as a result of a pilgrimage. The first scheme of paintings are fragmentary .
